channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tibet Protesters Hurt in Crackdown; Self-Immolations Continue
item.description: At least five Tibetans have set fire to themselves in recent days, and at least 20 Tibetan students were injured after security forces cracked down on a large protest in western China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Rebel Leaders in Congo Send Mixed Signals on Leaving Goma
item.description: The list of conditions, like releasing political prisoners and investigating the murders of opposition supporters, was long and unrealistic and meant that an immediate pullout seemed unlikely.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: A man said to be from a Rwandan rebel group was held Tuesday. Rwanda said fighters crossed from Congo and attacked a village.

item.title: Protesters Gather Again in Cairo Streets to Denounce Morsi
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi’s attempt to soften his edict did little to constrain the crowd, which some estimates put at hundreds of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Egyptian man was detained by police officers in Cairo during protests on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Top BBC Figures Acknowledge ‘Errors’ in Reporting Scandals
item.description: The remarks by Chris Patten, the head of the supervisory BBC Trust, and Tim Davie, the acting director general, came as they were addressing a parliamentary panel.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Chris Patten, the chairman of the supervisory BBC Trust, defended the former director general George Entwistle.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: As U.S. Shares Intelligence with Honduras, Other Antidrug Aid Stays Frozen
item.description: The United States has revived an international effort to stop drug planes from using the tiny Central American country as a way station for cocaine smuggling to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Hugo Chávez Will Go to Cuba for Medical Treatment
item.description: The Venezuelan president will travel for medical treatment, following a nearly two-week absence from the public eye, months after his cancer surgery.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Érik Izraelewicz, Editor of Le Monde, Dies at 58
item.description: Mr. Izraelewicz, a former top editor at two other French dailies, had been brought in two years ago to overhaul the newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: Érik Izraelewicz at Le Monde's headquarters last week.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Hungarian Official’s Call to List Jews Draws Condemnation and Protests
item.description: A legislator’s call for Jews to be registered as national security threats set off international condemnation and a protest outside the legislature in Budapest.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Baghdad Bombings Kill Worshipers
item.description: Three car bombs struck outside Shiite mosques on Tuesday, killing at least 20 people and wounding more than 50.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Bolivian Officials Arrested in Plot To Extort New York Businessman
item.description: Authorities have arrested six government officials suspected of involvement in a scheme to rob and extort a New York businessman jailed in a money-laundering investigation.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Ugandan Terrorism Suspects Say F.B.I. Interrogators Beat Them
item.description: Four terrorism suspects charged with killing 76 people in Uganda in 2010 say they were physically abused by F.B.I. agents, an international rights organization reported Tuesday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Portuguese Join Europe’s Chorus of Discontent
item.description: Protests and work stoppages have become much more common, as daily life for many Portuguese families has become a struggle to stay afloat.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters faced off against the riot police at the Parliament building in Lisbon during a coordinated European general strike on Nov. 14. The kind of demonstrations that have been seen in other countries facing economic crisis are increasingly common in Portugal.

item.title: Showdown at Italian Steel Plant Is Test of Monti and Economy
item.description: Thousands of workers stormed the Ilva plant, in the southern city of Taranto, after the company halted production and said that a court ruling warned of serious environmental problems.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Workers from the Ilva steel plant protested its possible closure in Genoa, Italy, on Tuesday.

item.title: Tzipi Livni Forms New Party to Oppose Netanyahu
item.description: Tzipi Livni, Israel’s centrist former foreign minister, returned to politics on Tuesday after a six-month hiatus, heading a new party.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israel’s former foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, on Tuesday in Tel Aviv. The new party she is heading is called the Movement.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Chile: 3 Abuse Victims Sue Church
item.description: Three victims of sexual abuse by a prominent priest filed a lawsuit for damages for what they claim was its negligent handling of their accusations.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: France Says It Will Vote in Favor of Palestinians’ U.N. Bid
item.description: The support from France is the most significant boost to date for the Palestinians’ hopes to be granted nonmember observer status, which comes with greater international recognition.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: A Palestinian honor guard left a reburial ceremony for Yasir Arafat, whose remains were exhumed in Ramallah on Tuesday.

item.title: Chinese News Site Cites Onion Piece on Kim Jong-un
item.description: It was unclear whether the People’s Daily in China had fallen for an Onion parody naming the North Korean ruler the “Sexiest Man Alive for 2012.”
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Online, People’s Daily quoted a satirical article calling Kim Jong-un of North Korea the “sexiest man alive.”

item.title: Copter Downing May Show New Syria Rebel Capability
item.description: Rebels hit a military helicopter with a surface-to-air missile outside Aleppo, a video appeared to show, marking a major battlefield advance.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD, C. J. CHIVERS and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: An image from a video posted on YouTube that appears to show a Syrian military helicopter being shot down with a surface-to-air missile.

item.title: Mexico Seeks to Recast Relationship With U.S.
item.description: In a meeting with President Obama, Enrique Peña Nieto, the Mexican president-elect, highlighted a more prosperous Mexico where high-skilled jobs were increasing.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Bombings Are Said to Kill Dozens Near Syria’s Capital
item.description: State media said at least 34 people died in twin car bombings in a suburb of Damascus, and witnesses reported that rebels had shot down a government aircraft for the second successive day.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HALA DROUBI and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Rebels celebrated on top of a downed Syrian jet in Daret Azzeh, 20 miles west of Aleppo, on Wednesday.

item.title: General Allen Investigation Narrows Focus
item.description: Pentagon investigators looking into e-mail exchanges between Gen. John R. Allen and a Tampa socialite have narrowed their focus to 60 to 70 e-mails.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH BUMILLER and SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Gen. John R. Allen testifying before the House Armed Services Committee in March. He is being investigated over e-mails he sent to Jill Kelley, who was also an acquaintance of David H. Petraeus.

item.title: Servicewomen File Suit Over Direct Combat Ban
item.description: Four military servicewomen, who all served tours in Afghanistan or Iraq, filed a federal lawsuit seeking to end the Pentagon’s ban on women serving in direct combat jobs.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JAMES DAO
item.media:description: Maj. Mary Jennings Hegar, a helicopter pilot who earned a Purple Heart, was among the lawsuit's plaintiffs.

item.title: Érik Izraelewicz, Editor of Le Monde, Dies at 58
item.description: Mr. Izraelewicz, a former top editor at two other French dailies, had been brought in two years ago to overhaul the newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: Érik Izraelewicz at Le Monde's headquarters last week.

item.title: News Analysis: Sunni Leaders Gaining Clout in Mideast
item.description: The United States is left somewhat wary about the rising Sunni Muslim alliance of Egypt, Qatar and Turkey and its potential for anti-Western sentiment.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman in Gaza City on Tuesday walked amid the rubble left from eight days of fighting that ended in a cease-fire.

item.title: British Lawmakers Join Fierce Debate on Press Controls
item.description: On the eve of the publication of a major report into Britain’s phone hacking scandal, a group of more than 80 British lawmakers launched a defense of press freedom.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
